answers.answer: Hi,How are you? Do you have history of Herpes Zoster or chicken pox?  Burning sensation and other neuropathies such as tingling, numbness and pin pricking sensations are often associated with neurological issues.It is best that you have this checked by your doctor or be referred to a neurologist for proper evaluation. Take care and do keep us posted.

question: I'm a 30 year old female.  I've only worked in office/call center environments.  This may be the 3rd time I've experienced this issue over the past 4 years.  It feels like I sat a hot iron on my leg & just let it sit there.  Right now it's the front of my right thigh that burns. Now that I think of it, so far it's only happened in this spot.  There's no visible injury, rash, redness, bruise, flakiness, etc... The skin looks normal.  Cold & pressure makes it hurt more than ever and low-dose aspirin are no help. There's no itching, tingling, or numbness.The only thing I have is asthma & allergies. I'm not on any medications. I've been tested for every possible STI/HIV-AIDs & I donate blood regularly. I'm not pregnant, unless you believe in immaculate conception. I'm not hypo(er)tensive and I don't have diabetes. I still use the same detergent, Tide (no bleach) and same bounce drier sheets. I'm at a loss for the cause, solution, or temporary relief options.Please advise, any assistance is appreciated.
title: Burning sensation on thigh
